title: IVT: Which is not nec. true?

content.question: Let g be a continuous function on the closed interval [0,1]. Let g(0)=1 and g(1)=0. Which of the following is NOT necessarily true?

choices.label: There exists a number h in [0,1] such that <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" aria-label="g of h is greater than or equal to g of x"><semantics><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>≥</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation>MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaWGNbGaaiikaiaadIgacaGGPaGaeyyzImRaam4zaiaacIcacaWG 4bGaaiykaaaa@3E50@</annotation></semantics></math> for all x in [0,1].
For all a and b in [0,1], if a=b, then g(a)=g(b)

There exists a number h in [0,1] such that <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" aria-label="g of h equals one half"><semantics><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mrow><annotation>MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaWGNbGaaiikaiaadIgacaGGPaGaeyypa0ZaaSaaa8aabaWdbiaa igdaa8aabaWdbiaaikdaaaaaaa@3C13@</annotation></semantics></math>

There exists a number h in [0,1] such that <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" aria-label="g of h equals three halves"><semantics><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mrow><annotation>MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaWGNbGaaiikaiaadIgacaGGPaGaeyypa0ZaaSaaa8aabaWdbiaa iodaa8aabaWdbiaaikdaaaaaaa@3C15@</annotation></semantics></math>

For all h in the open interval (0,1) , <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" aria-label="the limit as x approaches h of g of x equals g of h"><semantics><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>h</mi></mrow></munder><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation>MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaWaaCbeaeaaqa aaaaaaaaWdbiGacYgacaGGPbGaaiyBaaWcpaqaa8qacaWG4bGaeyOK H4QaamiAaaWdaeqaaOWdbiaadEgacaGGOaGaamiEaiaacMcacqGH9a qpcaWGNbGaaiikaiaadIgacaGGPaaaaa@44B8@</annotation></semantics></math>

content.answer: There exists a number h in [0,1] such that <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" aria-label="g of h equals three halves"><semantics><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mrow><annotation>MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaWGNbGaaiikaiaadIgacaGGPaGaeyypa0ZaaSaaa8aabaWdbiaa iodaa8aabaWdbiaaikdaaaaaaa@3C15@</annotation></semantics></math>

topic.text: 1.16: Working with the Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT)

skill.text: Skill 3.E: Provide reasons or rationales for solutions and conclusions.
